Consider the following background information: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician because of abdominal pain and constipation for 3 weeks. His mother says he has been increasingly irritable recently. His vocabulary consists of 50 words and he does not use sentences. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae and abdominal tenderness. He refers to himself by name but is unable to name body parts or count to three. Peripheral blood smear shows small, pale red blood cells with basophilic stippling.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: The patient"s ability to convert ferrous iron to ferric iron is most likely impaired.

supporting.text: The peripheral blood smear shows small, pale red blood cells with basophilic stippling, which is characteristic of microcytic hypochromic anemia, commonly caused by iron deficiency.

attacks.text: The peripheral blood smear shows small, pale red blood cells with basophilic stippling, which is characteristic of microcytic hypochromic anemia, commonly caused by iron deficiency.
Basophilic stippling is more commonly associated with lead poisoning rather than iron deficiency anemia.
Lead poisoning can also cause microcytic hypochromic anemia, which would explain the peripheral blood smear findings.
The patient's developmental delay and irritability are more consistent with lead poisoning than with simple iron deficiency.
Iron deficiency can also cause developmental delays and behavioral changes in children.
The patient's ability to convert ferrous iron to ferric iron is unlikely to be impaired as this is not a common mechanism in iron deficiency anemia.

Lead poisoning typically presents with microcytic anemia and basophilic stippling, but the absence of exposure history makes this less likely than iron deficiency.
